item.title: CTO at BIMLauncher Ltd
item.description: BIMLauncher Ltd develops and runs integrations between cloud software. The platform offers highly configurable and customisable workflows to be built between software for construction projects which enable data synchronization and migrations. From the digitilastion of the AEC industries emerged a new and important concept: the Common Data Environment (CDE). Many project management solutions were developed each offering a set of tools and claiming to act as the CDE but the reality is that across a large construction project, teams of different disciplines, geographic locations and even different stages of the project lifecycle, choose their own digital tools.

item.title: Owner and Director at Strange Labs
item.description: Taking my favourite experiences from the technology startup world: meeting enthusiastic people and sharing ideas, I created an environment where that could happen regularly. Strange Labs was the first technology Meet up space of it’s kind in the UK on the high street. Alongside this, Strange Labs quickly became the top rated computer shop in Bristol. Though the main business was through PC custom builds, repairs and upgrades, this simply funded the core idea: a space to facilitate technology discussion and discovery.

item.title: Co-founder & CTO at Jenca Ltd
item.description: Building on the idea of an open platform for building data, Jenca was an attempt to help democratize the building process by allowing non-technical workers found in the AEC industries to engage with open technologies. The premise was a platform which allowed users to run compile applications at scale. These applications were deployed as collections, which we called Projects. The platform was based on a NodeJS architecture running on Docker and Kubernetes.

item.title: Speaker at KubeCon Europe Conference 2016
item.description: KubeCon is the major Google Kubernetes conference in the world. I was invited to speak by the organisers based on the work they had seen on GitHub. I presented the story about how Jenca applied the Google Kubernetes technology to a new vertical industry- construction

item.title: Speaker at TE&CH Conference 2015
item.description: TE&CH was a technology and education conference aimed at fringe research projects gaining traction in the UK. After the success of the presentation at AEChack, BIMscripts investors invited me to give the same presentation at TE&CH conference. I presented it alongside the latest demo of our system.

item.title: Speaker at AEChack Conference 2015
item.description: AEChack is a worldwide recognised hackathon for the AEC industries. BIMscript was invited to attend to run one of the groups, and I gave a presentation describing the lean, agile strategy we employed as a company in developing software for the construction industry.

item.title: Speaker at World Information Architecture UX Conference 2015
item.description: World Information Architecture I was invited to speak at the World Information Architecture UX Conference in Bristol. I presented how to design web applications for people in the construction industry, specifically how to design an application which can be used by labourers on site and in the office.

item.title: Co-founder & CTO at BIMscript Ltd
item.description: BIMscript Ltd was a technology and BIM consultancy for the Architecture, Engineering and Construction industries. I took the successes of the society I ran at university and moved it into the professional world. BIMscript provided expert advice and implementation on emerging technologies including virtual reality, 3D printing, 3D laser scanning, photogrammetry and modelling, BIM implementation and strategy, and cloud technologies. Our clients included major construction and engineering firms VolkerFitzpatrick and Hoare Lea, among other clients such as FreestyleXtreme Ltd and the Foundation for the Common Good.

item.title: Co-founder & Vice President at Future Technology and Design Society
item.description: Whilst studying in the final year of my degree, a classmate and I observed that there was very minimal, if any, interaction between disciplines at university. We were studying Architecture and planning, yet we were not once advised to seek any other input to the subject than from the lecturers, classmates and industry professionals. We both thought, given the ongoing digitalisation of construction, and the future cities initiatives, that students and lecturers involved in other technical fields may have vital input into how Architecture can be done better.

item.title: Education
item.description: 2:1 Undergraduate Bachelor of Science (BSc) in The Built and Natural Environment from University of the West of England Level 2 Accredited Trainer for McNeel Rhino3D software Certificate of Higher Education in Computer Visualisation and Animation from Bournemouth University; 4 A-Levels, A to C, in Maths and Mechanics, Physics, Art and Design and General Studies; 10 GCSEs, A* to B, including Maths, Science, English;
